awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A SMART CAMERA SYSTEM FOR WATER RISK ASSESSMENT
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase I project is to reduce the loss of human life and property by providing improved current and future information to water management stakeholders. Rising sea levels and heavier downpours could increase flooding costs in coastal communities by $23 billion per year by mid-century. Traditional water monitoring sensors have major drawbacks, such as: constant maintenance, costly installation, and application-specific dedicated hardware.   Continuous monitoring of flood prone areas and optimized water management for freshwater conservation requires new technologies, including low-cost and robust water control systems to limit the loss of human lives, crops, property, and livestock. The proposed system in this project will offer a robust solution to monitor water and make weather predictions using deep learning algorithms. 

This SBIR project proposes to develop a cost-effective smart camera-based solution to perform a highly accurate risk assessment of flooding in public waterways.A key innovation is running sophisticated computer vision algorithms on a resource-limited platform. The proposed system will use low-cost LIDARs, generally used for measuring solid object velocities, for water velocity measurements. Furthermore, the project will develop a polarized-light system to achieve the system accuracy requirements, including real-time corrections of errors induced by visual impairments of the camera due to field conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

A SMART CAMERA SYSTEM FOR WATER RISK ASSESSMENT 

Pekosoft LLC

While some areas in the USA and around the world are prone to flooding and need real-time warning systems, in other areas natural disasters such as droughts are observed more frequently. In both cases, an efficient water risk assessment system can save lives and protect property. United Nation's climate report (August 2021) summarizes the extreme weather conditions that the world will face in the near future; heat waves that happened only once every 50 years are now happening once a decade, tropical cyclones/hurricanes are getting stronger, land areas see more rain/snow fall in a year, droughts are happening 1.7 times as often, average sea levels will rise 6-10 feet, coastal flooding doubled since 1960s, once a century coastal flooding will occur every year by 2100. All these extreme weather conditions require cost-effective and robust technologies.

Pekosoft developed a stand-alone, robust, cost-effective and low maintenance smart-camera based product, equipped with multiple sensors that can measure water level and water velocity and make predictions and risk assessment calculations advancing national welfare at the precipice of increasing water catastrophes. The primary innovation is the use of "smart-camera" equipped with sensors for water level and velocity calculations to predict water conditions by using real-time and historical data. The proprietary video-processing based system can trigger alarms based on user benchmarks and thresholds enabling the user to see the actual water body. The solution includes deployment of multi-copter unmanned aircraft system significantly improving the reach range for hard terrains, enabling dynamic event management and decreasing likelihood of user injury.

Advanced water level and velocity measurements by using camera control systems will help public and businesses to monitor and to prepare for natural disasters before they occur. Urban planners can use the system in the urban improvement or settlement projects for city planning. Street flooding prediction, street snow/ice prediction, landslide prediction, and other city planning related software modules are part of this product. Instant flooding in suburban landscapes where small bridges are located over creeks between low profile hills is commonly seen. Flash floods may yield dangerous conditions prior to municipal crew arrival for road closures. These conditions take multiple lives every year. Pekosoft's system can be easily connected to municipal alarm systems, and directly alert the drivers of this upcoming dangerous conditions. Management of irrigation/discharge water by using the smart camera measurement system will result better control of crops and help our nation's ability to achieve global food security. The system will have an immediate impact on the agricultural and environmental use cases since recent floods have displaced numerous farmers and significantly reduced crop yields.

Modified by: Burak Ozer

Images (1 of )
  • Pekosoft's deployed smart camera system at Brandywine Creek, Downingtown, PA. The camera can detect water level, velocity, make level prediction, and store images and videos. Measurements are done in real-time within camera . The results are sent to the database via a modem attached to the camera.

  • Pekosoft's camera sends the level, velocity, prediction results every 15 minutes to the database. Results are stored and displayed on a custom designed web-site. Water level results are compared with USGS results. The image shows Pekosoft and USGS results for a minor flooding on May 31, 2021.
